user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_digest_auth_calc_userhash:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN enum MHD_Result
MHD_digest_auth_calc_userhash (enum MHD_DigestAuthAlgo3 algo3,
                               const char *username,
                               const char *realm,
                               void *userhash_bin,
                               size_t bin_buf_size)
{
  struct DigestAlgorithm da;
  enum MHD_Result ret;

  if (! digest_init_one_time (&da, get_base_digest_algo (algo3)))
    return MHD_NO;
  if (digest_get_size (&da) > bin_buf_size)
    ret = MHD_NO;
  else
  {
    calc_userhash (&da,
                   username,
                   strlen (username),
                   realm,
                   strlen (realm),
                   userhash_bin);
    ret = MHD_YES;

#ifdef MHD_DIGEST_HAS_EXT_ERROR
    if (digest_ext_error (&da))
      ret = MHD_NO;
#endif /* MHD_DIGEST_HAS_EXT_ERROR */
  }
  digest_deinit (&da);

  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
  if (! digest_init_one_time (&da, get_base_digest_algo (algo3)))
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The call passes &da to digest_init_one_time which, by name and usage (later digest_deinit(&da)), is expected to initialize/modify the DigestAlgorithm object, so a non-const pointer is required. This complies with Rule 8.13. (Only if digest_init_one_time actually did not modify da would this be a violation — in that hypothetical case the parameter should be const.)
